results.title: Dogs, cats and rabbits
results.brief_description: An amusing animated non-narrated film in three parts. Part one: 41 Barks - animated impressions of dogs, drawn and barked by Eliot Noyes Jr. Part two: Catsup - by Lana Hoban with music “Alley cat” by Frank Bjorn, played by Bent Fabric and a cast of five cats Part three: Rabbits, texture, shape and fun with drawings by Bill Stitt. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Dogs in space [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Entertainment Media, Burrowes Film Group, Glenys Rowe and Richard Lowenstein
results.brief_description: A group of young people enjoy the summer of 1979 in the belief that they will never grow up and join the adult world. Action centres on a Melbourne household of punks, hippies, students and radicals who represent the counter culture and the punk generation living on sex, drugs, rock ‘n’ roll and television. Cast includes Michael Hutchence of INXS, Saskia Post, Nique Needles, Chris Haywood, Gary Foley, Joe Camilleri, Noah Taylor.

results.title: Dogs
results.brief_description: Explores the world of dogs and their relationships with humans. Indicates that dog ownership means responsibility and care and that humans can learn a lot about animal behaviour by closely observing their pets. Also shows dogs that herd sheep, help police and blind people and perform tricks.

results.title: Dogs
results.creator_credit: Dimension Films, Michael Murphy and Diane Belle James
results.brief_description: A group of dogs in the countryside and at home. The camera observes in a sensitive and detailed way: as the dogs explore a stream and drink, we see how their tongues work to toss beads of water upwards; the rhythms and sounds, the ways of relating and communicating that are special to dogs. Includes a brief birth sequence.

results.title: Dogpound shuffle
results.brief_description: A tender tale about two lonely wanderers, ex-vaudevillian dancer Steps (Ron Moody) and the drifting Pritt (David Soul) who goes wherever the odd job will take him. Steps is on the road looking for his missing beloved friend, Spot the dancing dog, when he first encounters Pritt. The two strike up a friendship and find themselves in a series of misadventures as they hit the road to find the missing Spot. A story for the family - one with a happy ending.

results.title: Dogma
results.creator_credit: View Askew Productions, Scott Mosier and Kevin Smith
results.brief_description: Director/writer Kevin Smith’s (Clerks, Mallrats, Chasing Amy) comedic interpretation of the Catholic religion caused controversy before its release and continues to do so today, despite Smith’s claim that “Dogma” is about rediscovering your faith in God and shouldn’t be taken too seriously. Dwindling numbers of church-goers has caused the Catholic Church to take desperate measures to ensure its survival, beginning the ‘Catholicism Wow’ campaign, in an attempt to boost the church’s profile. Renegade angels Loki (Matt Damon) and Bartleby (Ben Affleck), banished from Heaven following an argument with God and forced to spend eternity in Wisconsin, discover a loophole in dogmatic law that will allow them to re-enter Heaven, by passing through the arch of a New Jersey Cathedral. Unfortunately God- who happens to be a woman- has failed to return from her monthly visit to earth to play arcade games. As a result the fate of the human race relies on the last descendent of Christ, Bethany (Linda Fiorentino), who has lost her faith. Metatron (Alan Rickman), a Seraphim and the voice of God, informs Bethany of her responsibilities and that she will be assisted by two prophets, Jay (Jason Mewes) and his hetro-life partner Silent Bob (played by director Kevin Smith). The unlikely trio head to New Jersey, to stop Bartleby and Loki from entering the church, because if they do, they will have proven God fallible and will wipe out all human existence. Along their way they are assisted by Rufus (Chris Rock), the 13th apostle, who claims he was left out of the bible for political reasons (and that Jesus owes him $12) and Serendipity (Salma Hayek), a muse with writers block. Cast also includes George Carlin, Jason Lee, Bud Cort, Jeff Anderson, Brian O’Halloran, Janeane Garofalo and Alanis Morissette as God.

results.title: Dog's heaven
results.creator_credit: Short Film Studio and H Tyrlova
results.brief_description: Using wool fibre, a flexible material for animation, this film tells the story of a little black dog, slightly disappointed in his master, who has a brief sojourn in Dog’s Heaven. Instrumentation comes from three harpists, trumpeters, double bassists and a chorus.

results.title: Does it feel like a long ten minutes? (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Andrew Vial Film Productions, Liz Rust and Andrew Vial
results.brief_description: A educational program about the procedure of abortion. Shows a simulated pregnancy termination with both the doctor and the counsellor explaining the procedure to the patient.

results.title: Does Dracula Have Aids? (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Ken Chown and John Lander
results.brief_description: AIDS is the most publicised and least understood disease in Australia. This video may help to clear up some of the confusion as the discoverer of the AIDS virus, Professor Luc Montaginier, joins Australia’s most experienced AIDS specialists and community leaders to confront the ethical and social dilemmas created by the disease. Geoffrey Robertson’s Hypothetical on AIDS was filmed on August 12, 1986.
